item.title: North Korea Reports First Apparent Covid-19 Case
item.description: Kim Jong Un locked down a city near the border with South Korea and required those who had crossed paths with the ill individual to be investigated, examined and quarantined, according to a state-media report.

item.title: Saudi Arabia's Latest Challenge: Containing Covid-19 During the Hajj
item.description: As Saudi Arabia prepares to host the hajj pilgrimage next week, authorities face the unprecedented challenge of balancing their responsibility as stewards of the Muslim world’s most important religious event with the need to curb the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: China's Mighty Yangtze Is Heaving From Rain and the Three Gorges Will Be Tested
item.description: Since June 1, historic floods in China have affected more than 45 million people in 27 provinces; the economic toll is estimated at more than $16.5 billion.

item.title: China Orders U.S. to Close Consulate in Retaliatory Move
item.description: The U.S. and China each moved rapidly to shut one of the other’s consulates and evict diplomats, unprecedented steps that were followed by calls on both sides to ease rising tensions.

item.title: Goldman Settles 1MDB Dispute With Malaysia for $3.9 Billion
item.description: The Wall Street bank will pay $2.5 billion to the government of Malaysia for its role in the alleged theft of billions of dollars from a government investment fund, and guarantee the recovery of $1.4 billion in assets allegedly stolen from the fund.

item.title: Economic Recoveries in U.S., Europe Take Diverging Paths
item.description: The U.S. economy lagged in July and Europe’s bounced back, according to fresh surveys of purchasing managers, evidence that the two economic powerhouses are recovering at different speeds from the coronavirus pandemic.
